III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement.
Section (4) An agency shall consider all of the following factors in selecting
Description an appropriate placement for a child:
(b) The physical, emotional, and educational needs of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The relative care provider refused access to a room in the home
and indicated it had never been viewed by the agency, even
though the 3130A noted otherwise. The relative reported that
there was a hole in the roof in the room. When following up on this
several months later, the agency did not know the status of the
repairs.
Investigation The investigation was opened 02/21/23, to follow up on an
unresolved safety alert dated 4/21/22. The complainant, a DCWL
Manager, noted the following: On 4/21/2022 a relative refused to
allow a DCWL agency analyst to do a walkthrough of the home.
When asked if there were any safety concerns, the relative
reported her bedroom was off limits and had never been viewed
by the agency, although the agency noted in the 3130A that all
rooms, including the relative’s bedroom had been viewed. DCWL
completed a safety alert due to not being able to tour the home.
The relative disclosed to the agency the reason she refused to
allow a walk through was because there was a hole in the roof in
that room but stated no one used it. The safety plan was that no
one would use that room until repairs were made, and the relative
was to seek quotes from contractors so resources could be
secured for the repairs. As of 2/17/2023, the agency had no idea
whether the repairs were made or not.
The agency was notified of the investigation on 2/24/23. The
relative care provider took placement of her great nephew on
8/6/21. He was 17 years old at the time of placement.
Documentation reviewed:
Review of the relative placement home study (3130A), dated
8/30/21, completed by Staff 1. The 3130A does not identify any
safety alerts or issues and does not include any information about
a hole or holes in the ceiling. The author of the report is no longer
employed with the agency and therefore cannot verify the
condition of the home and the rooms that were observed.
2

Review of the safety alert dated 4/21/22. Safety alert indicates the
relative refused entry of the analyst into her home to review for
any safety concerns. The relative indicated the bedroom was off
limits and had never been viewed by the agency. The safety alert
has the agency’s response on the bottom of the alert which
indicates Staff 1 did a complete walk through of the home on
11/11/21 (Initial 3130 A was dated 8/30/21) to complete the
3130A. The worker confirmed she did a complete home tour and
viewed all of the rooms including the relative's bedroom. The
relative decided to not move ahead with licensure and the
licensing case was closed by the agency on 2/8/22. On 4/21/22,
the foster care worker was out at the home and the relative
disclosed to her that she didn't let the DCWL analyst in because
the home has a hole in the roof that is located in an unused
bedroom. A safety plan was developed by the agency and the
relative regarding the bedroom with the hole in the ceiling.
Review of the safety plan dated 4/22/22. The safety plan outlines
that the relative and youth living in the home will not use the
bedroom that has the hole in the ceiling and that the relative
agrees to get quotes to have the hole repaired. The relative and
youth both agreed to notify the agency if any safety concerns
arise.
Review of the Updated 3130A completed on 8/30/22. The report
indicates there is ceiling damage in a bedroom on the first floor
and a hole in the ceiling in a bedroom on the second floor. The
report indicates the relative will be getting an estimate by 9/9/22
for the repairs.
Interviews:
I interviewed the DCWL analyst via phone on 2/27/23. She
reported she did not view the rooms in the relative's home as the
relative refused. She reported she emailed with the agency’s
Licensing Supervisor on 2/20/23, who reported the relative is
refusing resources to fix the ceilings. The relative caretaker
reported she only wants a relative to complete the repairs. She
reported a relative did make repairs to stop the leakage upstairs
but didn't repair the drywall and the hole in the ceiling remains. No
work has been done on the lower-level damage.
I interviewed the relative care provider on 2/28/23 via the phone.
She reported that two staff members from the agency saw the
hole in her ceiling around the time her nephew was placed in her
home. The relative care provider reported she didn't like the
DCWL analyst that came out in April, and she did not tell her the
3

truth when she said the agency staff had not seen the hole in the
bedroom ceiling. The relative care provider reported staff from the
agency did see all the rooms in the house. The relative care
provider did not let the analyst walk through her home. There was
only one hole in the downstairs bedroom at the time her nephew
was placed in her home, and no one occupied that room. The
relative care provider reported that her nephew's bedroom is
upstairs and does not have any issues with the ceiling/leaks.
There is an additional bedroom upstairs that has developed a leak
and this room is also not occupied. The relative care provider
reported that the leak was recently fixed but the hole in the ceiling
remains. The relative care provider reported she is 72 years old
and on a fixed income and cannot afford to fix the roof of her
home, but she is slowly working on trying to get a person to fix the
holes in the ceiling. The relative care provider reported she was
asked to get repair estimates from the agency but has not
provided them. The relative care provider denied that the agency
had offered funds/FIG to assist with fixing the holes in the ceiling.
The licensing supervisor reported that the licensing worker who
did the initial 3130A did see all the rooms, as that is what she
reported in supervision. The safety alert indicates a home visit
was done on 11/11/21 when the report was dated August 2021.
The licensing supervisor reported that was a typo and the home
visit and walk through was done on 8/24/21. The Licensing
Supervisor reported that the relative has not provided estimates
as requested. They have asked for them and the relative is
becoming upset with them as she does not want to fix them. The
licensing supervisor provided a list of dates that indicated a worker
was in the home and assessing for safety. There were no noted
concerns related to safety and some months there was
documentation of discussing the need for estimates and how to
get the rooms repaired as well as paperwork to complete for
assistance with paying for the ceiling repairs.
Reviewed foster home visits forms that indicated the youth was
assessed to be safe in the home.
Analysis Based on interviews and documentation there is no evidence to
support the physical, emotional or educational needs of the 17-
year-old youth are unmet. His bedroom was noted to not have any
issues. The relative’s home has two unused bedrooms that are in
need of repair due to water/leak damage. Both rooms are not
occupied, and the agency developed a safety plan that was
followed by the relative. The agency made attempts to encourage
the relative to get estimates, but she is not interested in having an
4

outsider complete the work. The physical, emotional and
educational needs of the child are being met.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
The agency’s home visit form has a section related to safety. The
section has the worker assess and indicate if the child is safe in
the home. The form also has a section titled safety concerns. If a
safety plan is in place, it should be noted on the form in the safety
concerns section. The person doing the visit should be checking
on the safety plan compliance and documenting it.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
